Standard_Text: Partition circles and rectangles into two, three, or four equal shares, describe the shares using the words halves, thirds, half of, a third of, etc., and describe the whole as two halves, three thirds, four fourths. Recognize that equal shares of identical wholes need not have the same shape.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Partition a rectangle into rows and columns of same-size squares and count to find the total number of them.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Recognize and draw shapes having specified attributes, such as a given number of angles or a given number of equal faces. Identify triangles, quadrilaterals, pentagons, hexagons, and cubes.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Reason with shapes and their attributes.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Geometry
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Draw a picture graph and a bar graph (with single-unit scale) to represent a data set with up to four categories. Solve simple put-together, take-apart, and compare problems using information presented in a bar graph.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Generate measurement data by measuring lengths of several objects to the nearest whole unit, or by making repeated measurements of the same object. Show the measurements by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in whole-number units.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Represent and interpret data.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Solve word problems involving dollar bills, quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies, using $ and ¢ symbols appropriately.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Tell and write time from analog and digital clocks to the nearest five minutes, using a.m. and p.m. Know relationships of time (e.g., minutes in an hour, days in a month, weeks in a year).
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Work with time and money.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Represent whole numbers as lengths from 0 on a number line diagram with equally spaced points corresponding to the numbers 0, 1, 2, …, and represent whole-number sums and differences within 100 on a number line diagram.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve word problems involving lengths that are given in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as drawings of rulers) and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Relate addition and subtraction to length.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Measure to determine how much longer one object is than another, expressing the length difference in terms of a standard length unit.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Estimate lengths using units of inches, feet, centimeters, and meters.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Measure the length of an object twice, using length units of different lengths for the two measurements; describe how the two measurements relate to the size of the unit chosen.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Measure the length of an object by selecting and using appropriate tools such as rulers, yardsticks, meter sticks, and measuring tapes.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Measurement and Data
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Explain why addition and subtraction strategies work, using place value and the properties of operations.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Mentally add 10 or 100 to a given number 100—900, and mentally subtract 10 or 100 from a given number 100—900.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Use estimation strategies to make reasonable estimates in problem solving.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Add and subtract within 1000, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method. Understand that in adding or subtracting three-digit numbers, one adds or subtracts hundreds and hundreds, tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is necessary to compose or decompose tens or hundreds.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Add up to four two-digit numbers using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Fluently add and subtract within 100 using strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Compare two three-digit numbers based on meanings of the hundreds, tens, and ones digits, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Read and write numbers to 1000 using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Count within 1000; skip-count by 2s, 5s, 10s, and 100s.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: The numbers 100, 200, 300, 400, 500, 600, 700, 800, 900 refer to one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine hundreds (and 0 tens and 0 ones).
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: 100 can be thought of as a bundle of ten tens — called a "hundred."
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Understand that the three digits of a three-digit number represent amounts of hundreds, tens, and ones; e.g., 706 equals 7 hundreds, 0 tens, and 6 ones. Understand the following as special cases:
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Understand place value.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Number and Operations in Base Ten
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Use addition to find the total number of objects arranged in rectangular arrays with up to 5 rows and up to 5 columns; write an equation to express the total as a sum of equal addends.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Determine whether a group of objects (up to 20) has an odd or even number of members, e.g., by pairing objects or counting them by 2s; write an equation to express an even number as a sum of two equal addends.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Work with equal groups of objects to gain foundations for multiplication.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Fluently add and subtract within 20 using mental strategies. By end of Grade 2, know from memory all sums of two one-digit numbers.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Add and subtract within 20.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve one- and two-step word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Operations and Algebraic Thinking
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Look for and make use of structure.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Attend to precision.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Use appropriate tools strategically.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Model with mathematics.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Reason abstractly and quantitatively.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Standards for Mathematical Practice
